description.text:
Bronze Sculpture "DER GROSSE ELEFANT"
by Gottfried Kumpf, 1994

Naturhistorisches Museum Wien
Burgring 7, 1010 Wien

https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Kumpf
http://www.kumpf.at/de/werke

Scanned with Autodesk 123DCatch for gsi2015(TU Wien).
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40703 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=40703

Using the following options: pattern_radius = 4
pattern_rotation = 180
iphone_version = 1
pattern_thickness = 2
pattern_overlap = 49
case_thickness = 1.8
pattern_shape = 12
build_plate_selector = 0

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:735213

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=735213

Using the following options:

number_of_arms = 5
arm_compression = 1
height = 15
spool_diameter = 59
arm_end_diameter = 5
tube_diameter = 10
arm_thickness = 2.4
inner_diameter_backlash = 1
wall = 3
quality = 80
collar_thickness = 2
chamfer_depth = 2

I got the idea to build a Hovercraft last year when I read an article about Hovercrafts. From then I studied the topic and wanted to build one for myself.

This is my third prototype because the other ones had some issues.

  • They rotated around their own axis -> I could not control them
  • They could not carry enough weight
  • Small stones destroyed the propeller of the lifting motor -> I glued
    two bicycle tubes under the base.

For the design I used Autodesk Inventor 2013 and my printer was the MakerBot Replicator. It took around 3-4 days to print the third Hovercraft.

The base is not printed because it would take way too long. And Styrofoam has the advantage that it swims when the engines fail. I also did not print the bicycle tubes because they have to be flexible and they must be one piece so that no air flows out to the sides.

The Hoveraft is lifted by two motors and it has one thrust motor. The power for the motors comes from three 2800 mAh Lipo batteries.

My plans with the Hovercraft are to develop a cheap mobile research station for example for the arctic. The advantages are that it has no CO2 emissions and you can control it from another place like a drone.

Just ask if you have a question!

Here are two links to articles that have been published:

  • http://www.3ders.org/articles/20150709-jan-burstner-shares-design-for-awesome-3d-printed-rc-hovercraft.html
  • http://3dprint.com/77495/3d-printed-rc-hovercraft-2/
  • http://makezine.com/projects/3d-print-rc-hovercraft/

Here is the link for the video:
http://youtu.be/Cyb_-NWIL8A

I made it wth a Makerbot Replicator
Infill: 15%
Shells: 2
Speed: 75 mm/s

You can find a detailed instruction here:
http://makezine.com/projects/3d-print-rc-hovercraft/

You need:
Styrofoam base (35” x 14” x 0,8”)
Two bicycle tubes (28”), Extra Light (Around 0,31 pound)
Two “Hacker A30-12M Brushless Motor”
One “Pichler Boost 18 Brushless Motor”
Three ESCs “Xetronic 50A”
One Servo (Around 4,5 pound pulling load)
One receiver and transmitter
Hot glue
3x 2800 mAh Lipo batteries with 11,1 Volt
2x Propeller 9x6
1x Propeller 5x4,5

Print all parts once, exept:
2x Ruder 2.1
2x Ruder 2.2
3x Ruder
3x Akku
2x Verkleidung 2.1.4 or 2x Verkleidung 2.1.4.1 and 2x Verkleidung 2.1.4.2
2x Ring 1
2x Ring 2
2x Ring 3
4x Halterung
2x Hubmotor

If you want you can try it. I adjusted it with the trim function on my controller. I combined throttle and aileron for the lift motors. So if I push the throttle stick forward the motors run at the same rpm. And I can adjust the power of each motor with the aileron stick.
So you got water in the front motor? That's nearly impossible because there are two bicycle tubes which float and a styrofoam base. The motors are located over the base.
Jan

comments.text: Looks great ;-) I'm thinking of taking your design and make it to an autonomous vehicle by using ArduRover. However, I do have some upfront questions: Can you tell me about the needed prop-size, the motors that have been used, and if thrust and lift are powered by one or by separate ESC's?
comments.author: MORP

comments.text:
Thank you! That's a great idea. But how will you manage the altitude? For example on grass you need more thrust then on water.
I used for the lift motors two "Hacker A30-12M Brushless Motor" with a three blade prop 8x6 or a normal prop 9x6.
For the push motor I used a "Pichler Boost 18 Brushless Motor" with a 5x4.5 prop.
Every motor has its own ESC so that you can control the rotation speed of every single motor. It is very important because on water the front lift motor needs a higher rotation speed than the rear one. Otherwise the Hovercraft would immerge with the front.
comments.author: MORP

comments.text: Thanks for the info. Measuring altitude or lift isn't that complicated. I'm thinking of using a flexsensor as used in some RC hydrofoil-boats to measure the distance between boat and surface. Additiponal data such as velocity, power consumption, etc. might also be helpful in controlling lift via rpm.

title: Phantom 3 Camera Guard, wide and slim version

description.text:
The camera protection for DJI phantom 3 prof. is clamped in the landing gear and can be additionally secured with cable ties.
The length it is reinforced with 2 thicker bars.
I used thin structures to avoid too much air resistance and weight (14 gr).
In my tests, it was never in the field of vision of the camera.
Hope it could help you avoiding expensive repair. Enjoy!

Due to some comments regarding down camera and ultrasonic sensor I added a slim version. There is probably no area for a guard bar effecting none of the cameras and sensors. The Video Position System functionality may still be reduced. If somebody could test this, please post the result as a comment. Thanks
Printed with PLA, 100% infill 45°, 0,3mm layer height, extrusion with of 0,33mm since the structure width is 4mm. Should be no problem to print.

comments.text:
The ultrasonic Sensor works, the plate does not block the way straight down, but probably there will be reduced reliability.
The downward Camera will see the plate, so I assume it will not function properly.
But the main application for this guard is flying outdoor finde there is uneven ground. It is not recommended and not necessary when flying indoor.
comments.author: Scottty

comments.text: The ultrasonic sensor and the downward camera  not affected by this plate?
comments.author: TomoQuads

comments.text: Downward camera is completely blocked. Ultrasonic sensor is half blocked but it may get effected.. Great design but needs to be improved..
comments.author: TomoQuads

comments.text: Do you mean "completely blocked" in function? Regarding the geometric point of view the guard covers half of the down camera field of view. If you know how to test please check the new slim version. Thanks.

The White Cliffs of Dover constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.6 million polygons). The vertical scale has been made 2X to help features stand out. This map was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.

author: swcc21

description.text:
A toy torpedo to play with underwater at night.
You need:
2 copies of "light-up pool torpedo w- lights"
5 LEDS
1 capacitor
1 battery pack
Calking
Poly Cement or other adhesive to glue halves together
Wire
Solder & Soldering Iron

1. Print out two copies of file
  2. Put LEDs into holes
  3. Smear calking around LEDs, making hole watertight. (The 5th LED goes into the nose of the torpedo, so you'll have to put calking on the outside.)
  4. Wire electronics according to the diagram
  5. Secure the battery and the capacitor in the bottom of the torpedo
  6. Use adhesive to glue the two halves together.

comments.text:
Why have you put in a capacitor in series? Capacitors do not pas DC current through them so your circuit will not work. This should be a current limiting resistor. What is the voltage of the battery? because from your schematic it indicates that you would need about a 10V battery.
Each LED typically takes 2V so you need to know the battery voltage to determine the circuit.
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: If you have any tips on improving the series, please feel free to remix & comment them to me.
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: Well, I have no experience in electronics and such, so any mistakes in the circuitry are because of inexperience.
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: What battery are you wanting to use? Ill help you if you want?
comments.author: cfrary

comments.text: I honestly have no idea. Please help. I am hopeless at this and I don't even know what would fit, as I don't have a 3D printer!
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: Ok firstly I reckon you should use a 9v Battery because its one unit rather then having to buy multiple AA Batterys. With the LED's I would assume you will use the standard size (5mm) therefore your LED holes should be about 5.2mm in diameter, this ensures a snug fit (you will still need to waterproof it. I would also recommend putting a switch in so that it can be turned on and off, otherwise once you put the LEDs in and battery then seal it, the lights will be on constantly until the battery dies. This is the suggested circuit: http://gyazo.com/6a5fc6ea73bd857dbc08a4a5e8d1896b . The resistors can be a slightly different value (would reccoment a greater value but not by much) this will adjust the brightness of the LEDs. The current values would be the maximum brightness the standard LEDs can handle. Also a side note when importing your STL it places it high above the build p[late (look at the thingiview above) for best print it will need to be flat against the ground plane (it can be adjusted before printing but its a pain). I hope this helps
comments.author: cfrary

comments.text:
The circuit you posted is a dead short. Either the battery or the smallest gauge wire is going to get really hot fast.
I'm sure you meant something like this: https://www.dropbox.com/s/cn1dp5fq9knexxm/redo.png?dl=0
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: Ok, thanks a ton. As I said I have no electronic experience!
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: Thats alright, Im an Electronics Engineer. If you need any more help just give me a message. Feel free to use the image & Good Luck with your entry! Ill be uploading mine soon.
comments.author: cfrary

comments.text: How big is the average switch, so I can make a big enough hole?
comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: The switch will depend on what you want. there are loads of different ones but considering your going to put it in water and glue it in, I would suggest you get a waterproof one. I am in the UK and use RS Components and Farnell. I believe these are also available in most country's. I would look on these sites but it doesnt matter where you get it from, you can google one, each one will have dimensions which you can use. once you have the dimensions add 0.2mm to each side. for example a 25mm width would be a 25.2mm width hole in the model. this allows for the tolerance of the extruded material. The basic criteria for your switch is: a) it fits in your model b) its waterproof
comments.author: cfrary

comments.text: Thanks again, for the help and the luck. Good luck with yours!
comments.author: NoLiver92

title: Holder for extra screens on Ford EcoSport

description.text: I installed 4 cameras on my Ford EcoSport, 2 in front and 2 at the back, for parking aid, and 2 monitor screens inside the car. Normally 2 cameras in the front are displayed. The 2 at the back are only activated when the gear is reversed. This is the reason why only 2 monitor screens is needed. To attach the 2 screens on the console, I printed this thing. There is OpenScad file available for you to modify for your specific need. For my case, the screens, attached to this thing, are installed below the air-conditioner knob, just in front of the logo "Sync Microsoft". I use double sided sticky tape to stick 3 corners of this thing to 2 plastic sides and the rubber cover below. The wires for the screens come out from a gap between the rubber cover and the plastic console. You may want to print using black - in the picture I used white for printing to highlight the thing.

author: frogmangeek

title: Modular Rack System for Altoids Tins

description.text: Do you use Altoids Tins to store things?  Want to keep them in a neat little rack system?  You can stack the racks pretty much however you want.  Put them on your desk, egg-crate style, or mount them to a wall, cubby-hole style.  I tried to make this sturdy enough to assemble while using as little plastic as possible (and no support needed).

Printed at 0.3mm layer height with 0.5mm nozzle on a Mendel Max variant.  If you squish the first layer a lot, you might have trouble sliding them together.  I used 15% infill, but there isn't much that gets filled.

Wire

comments.author: thegreathoe

description.text:
An OpenSCAD script to generate a simple hollow cover that fits a small Kyocera Ceramic knife... since someone lost the one I bought for it! Grrr! It is parametric, so you can modify the width, length and thickness to make a cover for another knife with a similarly shaped profile Warning:
Knives will cut! Ceramic knives will cut you so quickly, deeply and cleanly you will not realise until there is blood all over the kitchen! Keep it sheathed and be careful! Note:
the dimensions were measured with a ruler from a simple pencil trace and may not be super accurate. The shape (triangular cross section with outline of the square root of a sinewave from 0-120 degrees rotated by 8 degrees) is also a guess but looks pretty close. I taped down the edges of the raft to prevent it from falling over during the print, you might need to do likewise

• Measure knife width, length and thickness and enter into "user_variables" section, to generate custom knife cover
  • Print with wide raft as it is a tall, thin, unstable object with noticable overhang.
  • Add tape to edges of raft to doubly secure part to platform!
  • Remove tape and clean up with a file and sandpaper
  • Place atop dangerous but oft used Kyocera Ceramic Knife
  • Keep your fingers safe!

Update #2:
I finally added the RC controller and a battery pack into the Tri-Boat and tested it for the first time.
I made some changes to the assembly:
I designed and printed a new set of propellers which ware easier to print and perform better. If you print the new propellers there is no need to add support, it is included in the model.
I also replaced the propeller's shaft by a piece of a radio antenna and used a small piece of a bigger diameter tube from the same antenna as a sleeve for lower friction of the shaft.
Please see my new video in the following link:
https://youtu.be/fMYB55ncFWA

Update #1:
Due to the limited load capacity of the previous design, I've decided to increase the floating volume of the three boats. In order to do that, I decreased the wall thickness back to 1mm but added internal walls to make it printable. I also increased the volume by enlarging the boat. as can be seen in the pictures and videos, the load capacity increased by 37%. For the previous design it was 92.9 gr capacity for one boat and now it is 127.8 gr.
https://youtu.be/ZxD0kDUqUvI
https://youtu.be/6GZJIJ6EhmY

Original text:
Hi, I designed this boat in order to test the ability to reduce water friction while improving stability. I started with designing the boat; same boat for all three places, but one of them is a mirror. at first, I made the wall thickness of the boat too thin (1mm) so I couldn't print it well. then I tried to make it thicker but not too much so it won't be too heavy. I ended with 1.5mm thickness which gave a boat which weights 19.2gr and has a floating ability of 82gr (calculated by the volume and water density). Then I designed the bridges and tried to reduce as much weight as possible. The blue parts were printed in MakerBot 2 using PLA and the red parts in Ecksbot using ABS. The boat is turning by rotating the front boat around the vertical axis using a servo motor. The boat is pushed by two motors in the rear boats. The total weight of the boat (including servo motor, two motors and stractural parts) is 192gr.
As it can be seen in the video files, the friction with water is very low and the boat can reach high speeds.
https://youtu.be/3DEQ8IyanvM
https://youtu.be/J_eyrU2FmGk

The assembly is straight forward. each part is attached to other using one or two screws only. I used a paper clip for making the steering bar (which connects between the servo motor and the front boat). for the propeller rod, I used a cloth hanger (2mm diameter) and connected it to the motor which a piece of plastic tube. The two motors are electrically connected in parallel. It is possible to separate the control of them and try to make the boat turn by operating them in different speeds.
In the test of the assembled boat, I figured that it will be to heavy if I will add the battery and RC receiver, and I have some ideas how to solve it:
It is possible to make the three boats with a little higher walls. also it is possible to use smaller servo motor and receiver. The battery I used for the tests is a 3.7V li-ion, one cell of 18650.
I painted the boats from its bottom side in order to prevent water leakage and improve its look.

Made because I just got the Vector and realized they expect you to mount it with sticky tape! Inspired by an awesome APM mount I found on the net that isn't made for the Vector.

FEATURES:

-Full silicone ball suspended mount

-Full capture of vector flight controller without using sticky tape or rubber bands!

-Lower mount has holes for standard 45mm x 45mm flight controller mounting found on many frames

-Mounts via slots with +-5mm on 45mm to adjust FC to multirotor center of gravity

-30mm through hole in lower mount for wire management

-All Vector FC ports remain accessible when mounted

If there is enough interest, I may release a modified version with a flat upper mount to drill custom mounting holes in for other flight controllers.

DISCLAIMER:: As always, this project is provided AS-IS. A loose flight controller in flight will likely cost you hundreds or thousands of dollars. It is your responsibility to ensure your model is secure, and I will not be held liable for any failure. If you don't trust it, dont use it.

:)

For best results, print with 0.4mm or smaller nozzle, 0.1mm layer height.

REQUIRED PARTS:

-(4) 5mm silicone ball mounts
(designed around HK 5mm x 14mm silicone ball mounts with 3mm bore diameter)

-(4) 3mm or smaller diameter screws to secure lower mount to your multirotor frame

-(1) 18mm or smaller velcro strap to secure rear of flight controller to provided loops on upper mount

::HIGHLY RECOMMENDED::

(4) retaining bolts and nuts to secure the silicone mounts during high speed maneuvering

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS:

See completed assembly image above.

NOTE 1: Printing the retainer separately alleviates the support issue that would have occurred had it been made as one piece. The retaining clip tabs are 1mm longer than the wall thickness of the slots on the upper mount. This was by design, but the tabs are just a bit too long for the flex allowed by the upper mount uprights. Until I get it fixed, I recommend simply cutting them short enough to snap them in long enough to glue/epoxy. If anyone prints using ABS and ends up with enough flex to get them in, please comment!

NOTE 2: The upper mount cavity is slightly larger than the vector in all dimensions (<1mm). This is to accommodate differences in print quality, flow rate error, etc. I am mounting mine with a piece of HK 3mm anti-vibe foam pad under it to force it snug against the retaining clip and strap. YOU MUST PLACE SOMETHING UNDER THE FLIGHT CONTROLLER TO SNUG IT UP AND KEEP IT FROM VIBRATING IN THE MOUNT!

description.text: My friend is having his baby blessed and here is a set of cuff links with his daughters first initial on them.

My other designs for irrigation spreaders don't work exceptionally well if you have less-than perfect water; as in a few pieces of leaf floating in them. This is designed to have a larger opening, and therefore be more tolerant of the occasional piece of detritus. A side-effect is, of course, higher flow. The picture was taken with a purely gravity-fed flow from about 4 feet high. It does produce quite a nice wide pattern. I uploaded two files; one is a single sprayer, and another is four at a time. Since they're quite small, it helps to make several at a time so the previous layers get time to cool. It fits 1/4" irrigation tubing quite snugly; I would recommend inserting them with pliers, or perhaps sanding just a bit off of the ridge. In any case, they're not going to come out under siphon-level pressures.

I made these out of white PLA on a Flashforge Creator X clone from Monoprice, at 220 degrees. You might have a bit of a problem getting the angle down, as its close to 45 degrees and unsupported on the end; take it slow and reduce your temperature if necessary. I use painters tape on an unheated bed, with hair spray; I had no problems with adhesion. If you do, you might consider adding a raft.

description.text: A socket wrench with a different sized drive at each end. Download the STL file for a 1/4" drive at one end and a 1/2" drive at the other, or customize the included scad file for whatever size wrench and drive(s) you need. Set either of the drive sizes to zero for a wrench with only one drive. Goes great with my parametric hex socket.

• Print the wrench (wrench.stl or wrench.scad).
  • Optionally, use socket.scad to generate whatever size socket(s) you need. Or print socket.stl for a 7mm socket with a 1/4" drive hole.
  • Fit the socket onto the wrench.
    • To adjust fit, use the tolerance variable in the socket or wrench scad file, or sand/file the wrench's drive.
  • Use it!

author: cdragan

description.text: plataforma para carga de iPhone 5

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:862438

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=862438

Using the following options:

text = Robots Rock!
wheel_diameter = 55
fudge_factor = 0
features = text
letter_height = 9
letter_depth = 2
letter_spacing = 1.2
font = orbitron.dxf

Unlike the original (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11190)
I made a smaller head, without the spring, but with joints.
Behind the robot there is not the fake winding key and there are some other minor changes.
Like the original, I divided the prints into "plates" (in this case 5).
I have printed 65% of the original size (for my little cousin, his name is Gabriel, so I customized my robot with a "G" on his chest, as in the picture.)
so it came to a height of about 12 cm.
The head that I modified has a support created with MeshMixer.
For the joints, I recommend a drop of oil ;-).
----- ITA -----
A differenza dell'originale (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11190)
ho fatto la testa più piccola, senza molla ma a incastro.
Dietro al robottino non c'è la finta chiave per la carica e ho fatto qualche altra modifica minore.
Come l'originale ho suddiviso le stampe per "plates" (in questo caso 5).
Io l'ho stampato al 65% della grandezza originale (per il mio piccolo cuginetto, il suo nome è Gabriele, per questo ho personalizzato il mio robottino con una G sul petto, come in foto.)
così è venuto di un'altezza di circa 12 cm.
La testa da me modificata ha già il supporto creato con MeshMixer.
Per gli incastri consiglio una goccia d'olio ;-)

printed in PLA (only orange parts are in ABS)
PLA is harder and more difficult to fit, but it takes better grip.
----- ITA -----
stampato in PLA (solo le parti in arancio sono in ABS)
Il PLA è più duro e più difficile da incastrare, ma tiene meglio la presa.

author: pezzy

description.text:
The world famous 154,093 ton bridge can now be yours!
Built from 1933 to 1937, you can make it in less than a day!

Designed totally in Fusion 360

How to print:
I fixed the files so it would be easier to make and be able to be printed at a larger scale.

You need to print the Golden Bridge 1/4 4 times at 0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill, rafts and supports

On the Makerbot 5th Gen, it took about 48 hours

comments.text:
It seems there is a small flaw in the lower stantion of the single segment model. It can even be seen in "Thingiview".
Looking closely at the leg that is further from the deck, there are 3 points that are not totally attached. Printing this in Afinia Studio and it's considering them are two parts.
comments.author: chabot_morgan

comments.text:
Does this affect the print quality?
I will try to fix this

comments.text: Ill try to update a new file soon, but in the meantime, you could hotglue the parts together as you're going to do it anyway for the supports to the main bridge

comments.text:
I printed this with the settings listed in the details. Didn't turn out right at all. Before I went to bed I slowed it down to 50% and I'm wondering if slowing it down caused it to not print correctly. Also because I knew I wasn't going to keep it, the support and raft were next to impossible to remove from it without breaking it. So even if I reprinted it at a faster speed the supports and raft were insane.

author: ozanbdr

description.text:
For the most part, this is identical to Thorped's design as I reverse engineered it. Admittedly it is 3mm narrower than his.

Reason for this remix is because the original front foot did not fit my printer, but that could actually have been a bad slicing job.
See here for details: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:144716

Foot inserts to be printed in flexible filament. (I don't have any, so I am waiting on a friend.)

When printing, rotate the part by 90deg so that it is orientated in the same configuration as you would install it in.

Printer is 95mm wide and front and rear fits nice and snug, really snug.

I've installed the foot inserts now and they work like a charm. I really had to force them in, so as a result I'll alter the dimensions slightly for an easier fit.

I printed mine at a 0.2mm layer height and 3 shells.
And I think an infill of 30%.

text = Lisa
a prototype for a tooth brush holder. will come out with better versions later that will suction cup to a mirror for now its screw into the wall. till more design experiance
Exactly as the title suggests, this is a working pneumatic car that has been built and tested and has been proven to work, please have a go yourself and have fun with it.

http://youtu.be/itVS2QqAFkw
https://youtu.be/IOsXGuvhE4M

  • Heres the vehicle in action.

Hi, so the files provided are for you to print the majority of the necessary parts for the vehicle, there are a few other bits that will need to be purchased in terms of pneumatic components etc.

Additional items needed to complete vehicle;
-Pneumatic tubing (6mm ext)
-Pneumatic Ball Valve (6mm connections)
-Pneumatic Coupling Connector (6mm connection)
-Pneumatic Bulkhead Fitting (6mm connections)
This link is where I purchased the items for my vehicle - http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/261111761551?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Also you'll need
-Steel round bar (5mm diameter) - for the crank shafts, roughly half a metre should be ample
-x6 Deep Groove Ball Bearings 5x16x5mm

Okay once all parts have been purchased and printed construction can begin.

The two sections of the chassis are simple enough to assemble, glue and bolt the sections together and once set you will have a rigid chassis that can carry a bit of weight.

Now for the axles, the bearing can be pushed into the slots provided, note that the slots may need a slight bit of sanding to remove any rough points. If you just try forcing the bearings in you'll end up splitting the print at these sections, so be careful.

Once all bearing are securely in place the axles can now be cut to size, there are three axles that will need to be cut (front and two rear), please refer to the pictures. these should fit the bearing tightly but if the steel bar is a bit to big just emery cloth the steel down until the bar slides through the bearings. Wheels can be attached now or can be left till the end.

Now for the engine part!
The adaptor print, will eventually have to glued to the input of the engine which is located at the centre of the vehicle, pointing towards the front, again please refer to the pictures. but before you can glue the part in place you first will need to tap the female hole of the adapter to M6 thread, this will allow you to screw the coupling connector into the adapter. which once done can also be glued in placed to prevent leaks.

For the cylinder this should slot in nicely with the engine block, a bit of light sanding might be required on the cylinder shaft and the meeting face of the cylinder to reduce friction. Also the cylinders pivot will need to be tapped to M3, this is so a spring and be attached and secured with the aid of a nut and tightened or loosened depending on requirements.

The piston will need to be slotted onto the crank pin before both sections of the crank are glued together, I did have difficulties with this with the crank pin itself snapping due to its size, if this does happen to you don't worry, you can use the steel bar as a substitute and that works great.

Now with the piston fitted in with the crank all that is left to do is attach the rear axles to the crank wheel, for this I used glue which has been more that adequate. But when doing this be sure not to have any of the axle extruding into the internal space between the crank wheels as this may act as a obstruction to the rotation of the piston.

So with all those tasks complete you should have a working pneumatic car, in theory. But to make the vehicle automatous in the sense that it can run without a direct airline connection a pressure vessel will need to be built.

Now the one in the picture is a carbon fibre receiver that was built specifically for this project, if you can build one yourself great, but if not, do not worry there is a far cheaper and simpler option.
In my development for this project I did devise a 2ltr soda bottle receiver (as featured in the pictures), which with the additions I added managed to get the bottle up to 120PSI before catastrophically failing. obviously that is its maximum pressure and this vehicle can run on as little as 20 PSI, 60 will give you a good run so no need to get anywhere near that level. But for the construction of the soda bottle receiver I'll post it up in due course.

If you have any queries regarding the build please do not hesitate to message me, I'll try and help where I can.

remixed_from.title: Swirling Water Unit - Vortex water nozzle - Vortex Process Technology (VPT)

title: Swirling Water Unit - Vortex water nozzle - Water Dome version

description.text:
DUE TO AN ALLEGED PATENT BREACH THE STL-FILES ARE NO LONGER AVAILABLE, check out http://www.watreco.com/ Please do not contact me trying to get the files. check some alternatives
http://wasser-wirbler.de/shop/#!/~/product/id=38151160
http://www.wasser-hilft.de/martin_wasserwirbler.htm
http://www.kupfer-anton.de/shop/martins-wirbler/
https://www.happy-soul.de/wasserwirbler-aquanevo-juwel.html
http://www.wasserstelle-shop.de/wasserverwirbelung-etc/15-aquawhirler-wasserwirbler-4250188808882.html

Presenting the Water Dome version... original version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:894682 (or a funnel-version if the center piece is not assembled)

Use teflon tape (Thread seal tape / PTFE tape / plumber's tape) on all threads...

3D printed nozzle with magnets, creating Vortex water, to restructure the water molecules and thus vitalizing the water? Is it actually working? I don't know but there´s lots of info out there claiming so. I designed this nozzle to raise the awareness for our urgent need for pure water on this planet. If this design works... great fun! If you start thinking about how you can contribute in some way... OUTSTANDING :-)

The information collected here is for educational and entertainment purposes only. It is not
to be considered medical advice, prescriptive or diagnostic. See your physician for
qualified health care. And I do not claim that this design will work in any special way.

I was inspired by the work of many great inventors and researchers like for instance:
Viktor Schauberger https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viktor_Schauberger
Johann Grander https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johann_Grander

Why did it get my attention? Well lots of people claim that the water structure is very important. Like for instance: http://www.fractalfield.com/implodermagneticresearch/LukaszImploderResults.jpg
http://stud.epsilon.slu.se/5243/1/vagnell_m_130130.pdf
http://www.life-sources.com/pdf/lsi_magnetized.pdf
Also included some interesting youtube videos below.

So I designed this vortex nozzle to be 3D printed... Now anyone can download, 3D print and test if the alleged benefits of "living water" are true or not... (if this design is working that is...)

I´m the first one to admit I do know very little of how everything truly works. Also a true scientist will say that the "truth of today" is merely a matrix of theses hopefully reflecting the truth but they need to be questioned to be able to dig deeper, if that was not the case the development would come to a full stop and everything would be based on assumptions and belief...

ASSUME = "To ​accept something to be ​true without ​question or ​proof"
Urban version: "Do you know what ASSUME means? It makes an 'ASS' out of 'U' and 'ME'..."

BELIEF = "the ​feeling of being ​certain that something ​exists or is ​true" or "something that you ​believe"

this version has a 3/4 inch threaded part, you can use adapters and hose connectors or perhaps design your own.

Also possible to add magnets to test restructuring of the water. Perhaps water "remembers" toxins etc and acts like it still is in the water even if filtered out by carbon filters etc. Imagine what that does to the drinking water that circulates back to the tap from the sewers.
Magnets might restructure (reset) the "water molecule clusters" since the H2O molecule has a negative and a positive side. Lots of people are doing research and it looks like the industry successfully uses water treatment that suggests that it´s a fact...
(I will test these magnets: http://www.magnordic.se/shop/gummi-magneter-17x9-7624p.html )

I print without support and do not care about the fact that the parts are not 100% watertight due to the FDM method.
Consider using a FDA-approved material.

Since the 3D printed parts are a bit rough by nature you will get a better performance if you grind/polish the internal surfaces.

If it´s printed in rubber-like material it will perhaps survive running in the pond over winter?

If you'd like... Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament.

Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this:

This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design:

•The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc.

comments.text: So far, my machine is still agitating strong. I was tired of buying them too. I believe the PLA I used to print these is still a grade or two below the agitator plastic. comments.author: joepinehill

comments.text: thanks, i'll for your update.  and thank you for building the file.

Filament Spool Holder designed in solidworks. You can print in one piece if your print can fit it or print in separate pieces. The cut out on the top fits a .25 inch piece of tubing like I have used or anything you have. I superglued the seperate pieces together and they seem to be holding up. Measured width of filament spool, measured distance from surface and center of spool holder to figure out height of stand. Drew up a design in solidworks and seperated pieces in order to print on my printer. Glue pieces together and seems to be holding up fine.

author: yoannwyffels

description.text: Another part inspired by mnnthbx's Honda Ruckus hard parts, this time a light-less lazy eye, keeping it Swayze. Less post processing is required to get a nice looking part, and you can use the STL as a starting point for a customized headlight blockout with a design or signage.

Print in 20-50% infill. The blue part in the photos was not post processed, it's printed in PET+ and looks great as-is. The other was post processed with Bondo spot glazing putty then textured black paint and finally a few layers of colorshift and clear coat.

Inspired (obviously) by the MNNTHBX dingleberry, but without a plate mount and with modified styling. When you grind the rear frame's stock plate and rear light mount off a Honda Ruckus you're left either needing to immediately prep and paint or to cover it up. This part is just wide enough that if you grind judiciously you will be able to cover up the ground area.

Print them and use them but please don't try to sell them. There's enough post processing to make them pretty that it defeats the purpose, and if someone wants to buy one send them to www.mnnthbx.com for the original.

3d print at least at 20% infill. There will be post processing required to get the part looking nice. Don't bother with xtc-3d, just use Bondo spot/glazing putty, a couple layers with sanding should do it. I suggest printing with 3-4 outer lines since post processing may wipe out some of that.

description.text:

anyways, I did a super quick and dirty model of the lion hand, and it works, it even shoots out and everything. no moving jaw, so it can't hold the sword unfortunately, but we'll see where this goes.

let's see if we can bring some old toys back to life!

description.text:
A holder for tiny tea-cups. You don't have to stack them anymore, and they will hang below your cabinet.

This frame supports kabob sticks which hold the cups.

It is meant to work with kabob sticks and the holes have a diameter of 4.25 mm you may need to drill them out (by hand) to get them just right.

Mounts with a #6 flat head screw, the clearance hole is 16 mm deep. A 1 inch screw is probably perfect, depending on the thickness of your cabinet.

Print with a reasonably high infill and shells, the geometry is not very stiff.

Miniature bases with assorted cultural, religious, heraldric, or special-purpose symbols.  
No, I do not plan to post a Nazi swastika. You're on your own if you want one. It's not like they're hard to draw.   
Includes a prototype adapter ring to use these as 30mm bases for games that use that standard. This is not yet tested. Feedback is welcome.  
Updates as of Apr. 17 2015: Added iron cross, power button, classical omega, and stylized omega designs.  
Updates as of May 24 2015: Added antiflag design. Add whatever flag pattern you want with your preferred paint.  
Updates as of July 14 2015: Added elder sign with and without eye.  
Update as of July 31 2015: Added stylized Pictish Z rod and double disc symbol

Quick little OpenSCAD scrip to generate a roman emperor style coin or medal from a bust, using Bre's head as an example.  
The script is public domain, not Bre's head which I believe he still needs, from time to time. ;-)  
UPDATE: Renosis printed one out!  
UPDATE: Added another version that:  
a. Raises the profile up on a one millimeter ledge to make sure it generates several layers in Skeinforge before it starts to fill in the top.  
b. Recesses the profile into the coin/medal, with a raised edge all around.

Change the name of the STL file to match the bust you want to use, play with the sizing parameters if needed, hit F5 and if it looks good, hit F6 and export!  
I need to dig up those nifty OpenSCAD letter scripts to add a motto to this fine medal. :-)

title: Archimedes Windmill with airfoil design and generator

description.text:
update: 2nd design

  1. fixed a bug in sweep() and solved the problem of blade termination by introducing a wedge-shape. Hidden airfoil design is demonstrated in cross sectional view.
  2. added an airfoil-shaped 50 magnet ring to harvest electric energy. Stator coils will be fixed to bracket (not shown yet) after magnet delivery and 1st print.
  3. Intended practical uses: wind light, or charger. Sailing boat position light. Why not also harvest some river current with it?

Background and first design

Studying some logarithmic spirals I stumbeld over the Archimedes windmill patented and produced by a Rotterdam company called the Archimedes. Because I liked the idea behind it, I started to implement a first version to see it running, then a second version much closer to the original, because I also liked the design itself.

Obviously the company's windmill has blades made from metal sheets rolled around an axis and having no specifiic aerodynamic design. Although they claim an amazingly high efficiency for such a small wind turbine as well as a silent run, I suspected that a proper airfoil design might not be wrong - and also enhance the harmony and statics of the design.

So I started to implement a libary for NACA airfoil data and a sweeper to be able to seemlessly juggle around airfoils with changing parameters in 3D space on arbitrary trajectories.

Well, this thing is the outcome for now. I guess I also will add some terminal profile, but I haven't spent time on finding a good solution for this.

I added an STL file for direct printing. There I added a foot to stabilize the print. It is meant to be cut off after print to enhance aerodynamics. As shaft I use a 2mm bike spoke. I drill up the hole in the turbine (1.9-2mm drill bit) and heat the spoke before poking it in. The holes in the bracket I drilled up with 2.5mm. The bracket easily opens up 10mm to plug the turbine in.

bought 50 cylinder magnets DxH = 2x1mm to be glued into the ring.
The ring will be glued to the blades as shown in the design.

comments.text: Thank you for the response.  I have now printed tow of these things, one in PETG and the other in PLA.  The PLA print has much smoother surfaces.  Eventually I'll try ABS although print bed adhesion is a worry.  For the two prints I used supports and a raft and both completed without difficulty,  For the vane shaft I used carbon fiber rod which turns with little friction.  My next step will be to scale the print up to as large as will fit in my printer (135%), make sure the surfaces are polished smooth and the blades balanced.  After that, who knows?
comments.author: Loftonharris

comments.text: It would be be nice to see your prints as Make of this thing.
comments.author: Loftonharris

comments.text: Beautiful thing!!  Can you provide guidance on the best way to print the vane?  Yes, it has a nice little foot, but will this hold the entire vane vertical as it nears the end of printing?  I gent just enough drag from my extruder that makes tall and wide prints fail with regularity.  Might supports be useful, assuming they extend only from the bed?  Any advice would be appreciated.  And again, thank you for sharing this impressive body of work.
comments.author: Loftonharris

comments.text: Well, I printed it only once and it came out well. But stability in Z direction depends much on the printer. Stabilized mine before I started the print (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922538). As far as I remember I added some support (for 45° +) and used Kisslicer.
comments.author: Loftonharris

comments.text: the other main thing is , how does it orient itself into the direction of the oncoming wind with no tail finblade ?
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text: The bracket design has an off-centered-vertical shaft with hole meant to be used as pivot bearing. This should be enough. Have a look at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PNddursxCFE
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text:
I prnted, the stand didn,t come out well prob. because i didnt keep the bed hot enough to prevent a bit of warping.
The spiral came out ok , I am contemplating what to use and how to mount the shaft axes. I wonder how this performs vs. a a typ. wind generator blade set, efficiency wise - torque/rpm for a given windspeed.
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text:
Just got my printer repaired (some bearings were worn out, beside some other probs). Its printing the spiral right now. The ring came better after I turned it around 180°. The stand needs a bit of support. Came out well.
But this was a slicer problem (I use Kisslicer). As an axis I intend to use a 2mm bicyle a spoke. I'll post a pic and a film as soon as I have mounted it. I'd be happy to learn your results.
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text:
My dad was asking me the other day about dust and the bearings - yes, i did add an airfilter to the room and i need to get/clean the carpet out of there and it would be good to have some plastic bag to throw over the top so it doesnt collect dust and ruin the tiny ball bearings -- i printed at .375 with a .5 and it was about 3.5 hrs , with a non direct drive you could probably speed that up 25%.
I dont use kisslicer, I used to use slic3r - the material for the holder is just thick enough to stick a paper clip / thumb tack - those are juts about 1mm, I think you have to beef up the holding area around the axis if you are going to go 2mm. I was able to just stick an unfolded paper clip all the way in - of course the hole is about 1mm in it's current design. It seems to start turning with more of a sideways/ angle of attack wind than a direct parallel to axis wind direction. Thanks for your work - pretty complex curvatures !
comments.author: Parkinbot

comments.text:
Nice print. I printed mine at .2mm layers with a .5 head. Used slow mode as I had 2 head crashes at 75% print before repair.
My print took 6.2 hours for a hollow slicing. The wings got thin like paper at the ends. So cut it with a pair of scissors. Should try slic3r again, but it remember it being so slow.
After print I put it on the desk and blew on it. It immediately startet to rotate.
comments.author: freNRG

title: Connector and brackets for installing aluminum t-slot table on Probotix V90 CNC router

description.text:
These are two components to let you use MISUMI Part No.HFS5-2080-1500 t-slot. Unlike the factory option (which costs more than $250 without brackets), the entire table can be built for around $100 with shipping. I used 3 lengths of the referenced part number, for a total of 5 pieces 27" long, and an extra left over.

The small pieces are for holding the lengths together side-by-side. I used 16 total, 4 per joint. The other piece is to hold the table to the side rails. I have elected to use 5 connectors on each end.
For printing, I used PLA, .3 mm layer, 60% infill. These seem to be plenty strong for the application. Attachment is with #10 sheet metal screws.

author: gelly

description.text:
This is a pair of wafers that help protect my drawings and prints when I bind them together. A standard Prong Fastener clip will seat in the recessed grove. The bottom piece has a place for fingers to rest. The top helps guide pages as they are turned and folded over.

This was printed on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Generation using the Standard Medium settings.

Print with the flat sides down.

The larger piece is the bottom wafer. The tab on the bottom wafer is a finger rest. The smaller square piece is the top wafer. Using a standard Prong fastener, feed the male end through the bottom wafer and seat it into the slot provided. The tab should be pointing into the stack of pages and the narrow side facing out. Stack your folder, pages, drawings, notes, etc onto the prong clip. Place the top wafer onto the prong, with the narrow end outwards. Place the female part of the prong fastener onto the male part of the prong fastener while seating it into the slot provided. Close the prong fastener as normal.

Tips; Changing the bottom piece so that the tab points outward allows the tab to be used as a label.

description.text: We have wooden vents in our house, which do not have louvers so cannot be closed off. We had an air conditioner installed, and wanted to close most of the vents on the main floor in order to direct more of the cold air to the upstairs. I designed a vent cover to clip onto the bottom of the vent. This way it keeps the clean lines of the nice wooden vents, while at the same time forcing more of the air to the upstairs...
Simple standard print using raft.

author: Humanisticnick

description.text:
I needed something to keep the custom "pen" I made for my daughter's BoogieBoard.

The stock pen is much to long and pokey for a 2 year old, so I took a .5" dowel and cut it down, rounded the edges and made a blunt point. It worked great, but keeping it with the tablet proved to be a challenge.

I may later add some sort of string to the end, but I'm not a fan of strings and toddlers so it probably won't happen.

Solidoodle 3 w/ E3D v5 hotend on glass. I used a 5mm brim w/ SainSmart ABS. Printed at .2mm layer height because that's what I do.

Sketchup source included, feel free to make it better and let me know!

author: blindthingguy

description.text:
Monterey Bay. This is created with software I wrote to convert NOAA data into an STL file in a similar way to my SRTM2STL software. This data defines the map corners, size, area and vertical scale:

Total Area (approximate): 453.4 Sq. Kilometers (27.4 km X 16.5 km)
LL: 36.727/-122.085
LR: 36.727/-122.392
UR: 36.876/-122.392
UL: 36.876/-122.085

Vertical Scale: 1.5

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.

description.text:

I had a hard time finding s-hooks to my liking so I went and designed my own for my pots and pans. These fittings are for the Ikea Annons cookware set. They can be used to hold most pots and pans perpendicular to the rack but only the Annons Lids.

Future improvements may be made if brought to my attention.

The Photon Printer is a 3D printable laser engraver made from recycled DVD Drives. Software and build instructons are available in the downloads. A list of necessary components is in the instructions.

Legacy file are available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2277397

The Photon Printer started out as a quick weekend project then quickly escalated when I saw that there was room for improvement in the current designs. Designing the components was a fun exercise and the end result was satisfying.

Safety - None of the designs I have seen have any sort of shielding around the laser. Given that even a 5mW diode can be dangerous any sort of engraver should have safety features. These include
• A full enclosure to block reflected laser light
• Roller door access
• Safety cut off switch on door
• Angled ventilation to prevent light leakage

3D print-ability – Printing allows for a lot of features that are not included in other versions.
• Accurate positioning of components
• Fits a wide range of DVD Drives
• Z axis fine tuning adjuster
• Built in roller door guides
• Custom axis mounts
• Low part count
• Ease of assembly
• Buildable by people without access to machining tools
• All parts have one large flat surface to aid in printing

Features
• Coarse laser height adjust for material thickness compensation
• Fine laser adjust for focusing
• Spring tensioned Z adjust to reduce vibration
• Sliding lugs to fit a range of DVD Plates
• Fits a wide range of laser housings
• Suits an Arduino Uno and CNC shield for an easy build
• Low parts count
• Low cost

Video
https://youtu.be/hiiEqVzhY4s

Update
2017-10-04 Updated instructions. Software added.
2017-07-07 Corrected PPV3 X Laser Mount
2017-05-06 Parts strengthened. Laser holder modified to hold a variety of heat sinks. Laser driver bracket added. DC jack hole added. Instructions expanded. Legacy files moved to another page.
2015-10-01 Instructions updated, Solidworks and STEP files added
2015-09-27 A small gap added to top of nut traps to compensate for sagging during bridging.
2015-09-27 V2 uploaded - Now suits an Arduino uno with CNC shield. Sliding mounting lugs support a wider variety of DVD Drives. Springs are now printed, no need to tap the parts.
2015-07-17 Improved electronics schematic by pepperm
2015-07-15 Electronics Schematic updated in better quality.
2016-05-24 Step files updated

Instructions
First off get some safety glasses! The laser cutter is fully enclosed while running but you’ll need safety glasses for testing and focusing the laser.
A lot of inspiration and knowledge came from this tutorial
http://www.instructables.com/id/Pocket-laser-engraver/#step0
I’ll reference it a lot as I go.

DVD Drives
You’ll need 2 x DVD Drives – They must be capable of writing DVD’s if you want to use the diode out of them. CD Drives will also work but won't have useful laser diodes inside. They will also need end stops inside them. The newer the drive the more powerful the diode will be. After about 2009 they changed the diode package making it harder to use, so aim for something before that.

Here is a link on disassembling them.
http://www.instructables.com/id/Pocket-laser-engraver/step2/Rip-apart-the-DVD-Roms/
You’ll need
2 x linear axes with everything stripped off the sled
1 x red laser diode from the sled (keep both in case you break one)
4 x magnets from the lens assembly on the sled
1 x metal rectangle cut from drive case 100x80mm

Electronics
I’ve provided a simple schematic for the electronics that can be soldered into a prototype board. The laser driver relies on the regulation of the 5V USB supply. It’s not the best solution but it seems to work. For a better solution see below.
http://www.instructables.com/id/DIY-Laser-Diode-Driver-Constant-Current-Source/#step0 or
Or explore off the shelf TTL laser drivers recommended by Bernardo
https://github.com/305engineering/Inkscape

The 12V to power the fans and CNC board is from an external 12v source plugged intot eh DC jack.

For a DIY driver you’ll need

1 x 2N2222 NPN Transistor (or equivalent)
1 x 100 OHM resistor
1 x 4.7 OHM resistor 1W
1 x 22 OHM resistor 1W
1 x 100 OHM Trim pot 0.5W

Assembly
Print the parts on thingiverse.
Once all the parts are printed follow the instructions in the PDF.
Page 1 has a list of all the fastenings you’ll need

Software
I use GRBL - You'll need to recompile it as below or it wont home properly without a z axis
http://www.instructables.com/id/MicroSlice-A-tiny-Arduino-laser-cutter/step10/Software-Setup/
Never versions also have TTL as the standard laser output. f you aren't using a TTL driver you will need to change this.

Gcode generation
http://www.instructables.com/id/Pocket-laser-engraver/step7/Getting-the-software-ready/

comments.author: Surrbradl08

comments.text:
Yep, what Isolt said. I went through the same issue as yourself and the workaround I found was to use the GCode utility to send 'G92X40Y40' before each job. This sets an offset in the workspace so your negative coordinates shift to positive space. You can then use InkScape as you'd expect, although I have found you need to flip the image (which may be another setting I haven't worked out yet).
Try G92X40Y40 in a macro (if you're using something like Universal GCode Sender) and if it works for you write it as a startup block with '$N0=G92X40Y40'. This will then be sent automatically before each job.
comments.author: Surrbradl08

comments.text:
Yep 92 would be a good solution as well.
Sounds like your x axis is installed the wrong way around. Does it home to the right?
You could reverse your stepper motor plug but you'd also need to invert your homing direction in the firmware.
comments.author: AndyGadget

comments.text:
Very good point - I said in my comment further down that I'd gone my own way with the limit switches, and mine homes to the left. I've now reversed the X stepper, set $23 (homing direction invert mask) to 1 and changed my startup block to '$N0=G92X0Y40' and print orientation is now correct. Thanks for the pointer.
(Apologies Surrbradl, hijacked your thread a bit ;¬)

Can I just use a transistor switch and get power straight from the 5v regulator on the arduino?
comments.author: Isolt

comments.text:
There are a few ways to go about this.
The arduino is powered by usb because it's already plugged into the computer.
If you're using the diode out of a DVD drive the 5V on the arduino board should be sufficient. You shouldn't be running the laser off pin the "SpnEn" pin though, this should just trigger the transistor. If it's not burning then either the material you are trying to burn is too lightly coloured, the laser isn't focused, or the variable resistor is set too low to give the diode enough power.

comments.text:
FYI it's a good idea to not look at this while running, ever. You're using a class III laser outside of its enclosure, it's visible so all the damage will be on the retina as your cornea and inter-ocular lens will not block much of the light. Since the power output is enough to burn wood you're looking at a few hundred milliwatts of optical energy, and the wrong kind of back scatter can still deliver enough power to damage your retina.
This is a neat little device, but so few people understand how lasers can really screw up your eyesight permanently that it should be noted that this device requires some caution there. Using lasers with higher photon energies (blue) with the same total energy output is even more hazardous. The shield or other kind of beam blocker or attenuator needs to be between the user and the laser when on.
Ok, laser safety rant over.
comments.author: Mibben

comments.text:

comments.text: OK that'd be a laser focus issue. Are you using the same laser holder as in the instructions? If so wind the lens all the way in to get the shortest throw. Get a piece of black Paper or plastic then move the laser slowly closer until the laser dot is the smallest. Use the fine adjust screw to adjust the laser until you see smoke. If the laser seems very bright and focused but still doest burn then it's either not powerful enough (not a DVD burner) or it's not receiving enough amperage and the variable resistor needs to be adjusted.

comments.text:
Hi Azimuth45.
I'm glad people are enjoying my design! Hope you two have fun!
I haven't got around to updating the bill of materials yet.
I'm not an arduino expert but it looks like any of those options will work fine.
The Uno R3 is an official Arduino, so if you buy it the money will help support the Arduino foundation (sounds like some sellers sell fakes though, comments below say Mp3Car and Canakit are OK)
You don't need to buy a genuine Arduino though, the design is open source so as long as they're not claiming it's genuine that's no problem.
Anything UNO compatible will work. "R3" is revision 3 I believe, but is forwards and backwards compatible.
The ebay one has a smaller USB connector so there will be a bit of a gap in the case, but not the end of the world.
You only need 2 stepper drivers but a spare or 2 wont hurt. especially if you plug them in backward/

comments.text:
Looking good! From the looks of it everything is correct.
With a DVD laser you're never going to be able to cut white paper, it just doesn't have the power.
A 16x drive will probably be safe run at 200-250mA. So connect a multimeter and gently turn that variable resistor. If you see a sudden jump in brightness back it off immediately!
Once you're happy with amperage put a piece of black cardboard/plastic in front of it and move it back and forward until you find the focal point, you should see some smoke! remember your safety glasses!
If you want to push it further read up online about it. Apparently you can visually see the output change when it nears it's maximum wattage.

comments.text:
One note on the electronics
Question 12 http://www.schmalzhaus.com/EasyDriver/
"The Easy Driver is able to operate in 1/8th, 1/4, half, and full step (2 phase) modes. These four modes are selected by the logic levels on the MS1 and MS2 input pins. Normally, the pull-up resistors on the Easy Driver hold MS1 and MS2 high, which results in a default setting of 1/8th microstep mode."
So I think you can do away with those connections MS1 & MS2. I don't have them connected on mine and the microstepping seems to work fine.
As you pointed out that diode is probably superfluous.
VIN on the arduino nano can go unconnected as it's powered by USB.
Any chance you could update it?
Cheers

Just uploaded a new version with a better pencil holder in the back, improved wire wrap, and somewhat better geometry which may slice better with some programs.

https://youtu.be/6YkpHe28oiQ

This is a modular, customizable desktop phone stand with 360 degree rotation, with fixed points at 90 degrees. It should be able to accommodate phones or mini-tablets as large as 170-180mm high. This version of the holder has a peg for wrapping up the power/data cable and a small storage cylinder. You MUST download the related set of things, which actually holds the device:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:878682

This is just one of a set of device holders I'm gradually accumulating. The link above will be the clearinghouse for the set.

This allows you to use your phone at your desk while charging in both landscape and portrait orientation. Assembly is straightforward. There are 3 pieces which should just snap together, though it may be a bit stiff the first time.

This is only 1 of the 3 pieces, you will also need to download the set here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:878682

Notes:

  • Suggest a high infill to give it some mass so it doesn't slide around too much.

  • Pretty much any plastic seems to work well. I've tried PLA and PETC (with a couple of pieces in ABS).

  • I've printed this with as large as a 0.75mm nozzle and a 0.5mm step. However, even though it's a "bulk" piece, there are a few small details which come out much better with a finer step and smaller nozzle. This will take several hours to print, even on a pretty fast printer.

  • If the little lump on the surface of the stand itself doesn't print well, you may be able to drill it out and replace it with small piece of smoothed wire, a small bearing or similar. The lack of this piece will simply mean the holder won't lock well at 90 degree increments.

  • Generally if you need to take it apart, you can probably just give it a firm pull. If the latch mechanism gets stuck, there is a small hole about paper-clip size near the end of the barrel on one side. If you push there (with a paper clip), you should be able to disengage the latch.

  • I haven't found it necessary to use the screw-holes on the phone holder piece to latch the phone in place. Gravity does a nice job. If your cable is torquing your phone and it won't stay in place, you can print out 3-5 of the optional latch pieces and screw them into the holder so they can be rotated. Alternatively, you can screw a rubber grommet into each spot.

Modified Foldable Multi Tool
https://youtu.be/tIqHIXEb5gE

description.text:
Title really says it all. It's a destiny themed bank. Trying to motivate my nephew to save and he loves the game so I figured i'd give it a shot. Currently the only way into this bank is to break it (I designed it that way to deter him from taking his money out. Since he likes destiny my hopes are he wont want to break it -crossing fingers- )

Future goals: Design a way into the bank without breaking it.

Enjoy
